alert.note: Alert for Dillon; Horry; Marion (South Carolina) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.senderName: NWS Wilmington (Northeastern South Carolina and Southeastern North Carolina - Wilmington)
info.headline: Flood Warning issued December 20 at 9:45AM EST until December 21 at 7:00PM EST by NWS Wilmington
info.description: ...The Flood Warning is extended for the following rivers in North Carolina...South Carolina... Cape Fear River At William O Huske Lock And Dam 3 affecting Bladen and Cumberland Counties. Lumber River 1 SE Nichols affecting Horry, Marion and Dillon Counties. ...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in South Carolina... Waccamaw River At Conway affecting Horry County. Great Pee Dee River At Pee Dee affecting Marion and Florence Counties. Little Pee Dee River At Galivants Ferry affecting Horry and Marion Counties. ...The Flood Warning is cancelled for the following rivers in South Carolina... Black Creek At Quinby affecting Darlington and Florence Counties. For the Cape Fear River...including William O Huske Lock And Dam 3, Elizabethtown, Lock And Dam 1...Minor flooding is forecast. For the Lumber River...including Nichols, Pembroke, Lumberton Usgs Gage, Maxton, Lumberton, Boardman...Minor flooding is forecast. For the Little Pee Dee River...including Galivants Ferry...Minor flooding is forecast. For the Waccamaw River...including Freeland, Above Conway, Conway, Aiw At old Hwy 544 At Socastee, Longs...Minor flooding is forecast. For the Great Pee Dee River...including Bennettsville 10sw, Pee Dee...Minor flooding is forecast. ...FLOOD WARNING NOW IN EFFECT UNTIL TOMORROW EVENING... * WHAT...Minor flooding is occurring and minor flooding is forecast. * WHERE...Lumber River 1 se Nichols. * WHEN...Until tomorrow evening. * IMPACTS...At 20.0 feet, Minor flooding along River Road east of Nichols on the Horry County side of the river begins. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 9:00 AM EST Wednesday the stage was 20.0 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to rise to a crest of 20.1 feet this afternoon. It will then fall below flood stage tomorrow morning. - Flood stage is 20.0 feet. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood &&
info.instruction: Turn around, don`t drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood deaths occur in vehicles. Additional information is available at water.weather.gov/ahps2/index.php?wfo=ilm . The next statement will be issued by this morning.
